thimos.proverb: Agikuyu moi kuhitha ndia, matiui kuhitha uhoro.
thimos.translation: The Kikuyu know how to conceal their quiver, but donot know how to conceal their secrets.
thimos.note: The Kikuyu, though very clever in concealing their arms, cannot keep secrets from the members of their tribe.

thimos.proverb: Cira munene ni wa uthoni ugikua
thimos.translation: The breaking of a betrothal is no small matter.
thimos.note: Marrying a girls means giving a large number of goats or cattle to her family. Starting from the day of the betrothal the price is paid gradually. Evidently it is no simple matter if the would-be husband breaks his contract and demands the return of the marriage price.

thimos.proverb: Aka eri ni nyungu igiri cia urogi.
thimos.translation: Two wives are two pots full of poison
thimos.note: The more women you have in your house, the more troubles you must expect.

thimos.equivalent: The world is a great book, of which they that never stir read only one page.

thimos.translation: To eat much leaves you with a swollen belly.
thimos.equivalent: Enough is as good as a feast.

thimos.translation: The cow is given a present when her calf is carried away.
thimos.equivalent: When one thing distresses you, another consoles you.

thimos.translation: One finger does not kill a louse.
